results.title: Everybody's prejudiced
results.creator_credit: Donald Brittain, Peter Jones and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Everybody? Well, there is prejudice and prejudice. From the man who refuses his breakfast egg because experience tells him to, to the man who dislikes his new neighbors for no reason at all, this film offers examples of prejudice that everyone will recognize and wish to discuss.

results.title: Everybody's business: management in action (NP)
results.creator_credit: Mark Davis, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description: Today the workplace is changing. Quantum changes in the world economy, in technology and in society itself have brought about a revolution in the nature of work. Increasing use of self-management strategies have led to a far greater sharing of management functions through the whole workforce. The classic functions of management - planning, organising, leading, and controlling are becoming everybody’s business, hence the title of this series. Throughout the series, reporter Cheryl Hall explores the new approaches to management in all sectors of the workforce. Kerry O’Brien speaks to experts on the key issues of management today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mark Davis, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia

results.title: Every valley
results.creator_credit: Michael Clarke, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: An impression, from daybreak to midnight, of the life of the industrial valleys of South Wales and of the growing part played in that life by bus and railway. The free verse spoken by Donald Houston acts as a link between various arias, choruses and orchestral interludes from Handel’s “Messiah” that utter their own comment, lyrical, ironic or humorous, upon the pictures of Welsh life and landscape they accompany.

results.title: Every step a giant step
results.creator_credit: Peter Hollander and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Community development in a village in Rajasthan, India. Shows how modern techniques introduced at this level can raise living standards, emphasising self-help.

results.title: Every second counts
results.brief_description: This film is specifically aimed at the prevention of home accidents among children, but if they do occur then it also firmly spells out the immediate emergency procedures to follow. This documentary was produced with the cooperation of the Melbourne Royal Children’s Hospital. Viewing of this program should be restricted to parents or guardians.

results.title: Every second counts
results.brief_description: Every second counts when a bushfire rages. Fire towers, well trained crews and equipment stands by the roadside are all part of the fire fighting organisation maintained by the SEC for the protection of the Kiewa hydro-electric power scheme. Prevention methods include the construction of fire trails and the planting of green summer grasses.

results.title: Every minute counts
results.brief_description: This film tells the story of a supervisor who becomes worried by the incidence of absenteeism and tardiness in his department. His superintendent points out many of the causes to him, and he takes steps to remedy them.

results.title: Every Inch of the Way
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Susan Lambert and Film Australia
results.brief_description: At the end of World War II, 14,000 Australians were released from Japanese POW camps in Asia. 8,000 of their comrades had died in the same camps and many of the survivors released were virtual walking skeletons. In this program, survivors of the camps (including Nurse Vivian Bullwinkel) describe their experiences during the war and the effect it has had on their lives and their families. Even now, decades later, they still fight the memories of the brutality, starvation, disease and trauma to which they were subjected.

results.title: Every five minutes
results.creator_credit: Max Anderson, John Taylor and Basic Films
results.brief_description: Illustrates causes of domestic outbreaks of fire and the precautions to be taken with them. Nearly all fires are caused by carelessness - leaving on electric appliances, using the wrong kind of fusewire, patching up electrical leads, leaving open fires unattended, and also leaving matches within reach of children. Emphasises that while fire brigades are highly trained, well equipped and within easy reach, the best cure for fire is prevention.

results.title: Every drop to drink
results.creator_credit: Mary Francis, Ralph Bond, Metropolitan Water Board and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: Shows how the Board meets the problem of supplying water to the huge population of London. Describes the supply sources from the Rivers Lea and Thames, and also from wells sunk in chalk subsoil; shows the purification plants and laboratories safeguarding the health of Londoners; describes the enormous reticulation and pumping system which serves an area of 54 square miles; shows also the installation of new pumping equipment and other plant to keep pace with the ever-growing demand for more water.
